spanishExample: ¡Da unas de esas cosas!
englishTranslation: Give some of those things!

spanishExample: ¿Cuáles historias quieres? Me da lo mismo.
englishTranslation: Which stories do you want? It’s all the same to me.
vocabIncluded: me da lo mismo: "it's all the same to me" (idiom)

spanishExample: ¿Cuáles son las mejores cosas que te ha dado?
englishTranslation: Which are the best things that she has given you?
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: ¿Quiénes son esas chicas?
englishTranslation: Who are those girls?

spanishExample: ¿Quiénes son los que estaban en tu fiesta?
englishTranslation: Who are the ones that were at your party?
vocabIncluded: "los que" to mean "which" after a preposition

spanishExample: ¿Tienes un *book?* Él te dará muchos.
englishTranslation: Do you have a book(m)? He will give you many.
vocabIncluded: dará: "will give", "he/she/it will give" (Dar, future, 3rd person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Dale la oportunidad, aunque no la quiere.
englishTranslation: Give him the chance, even though he doesn’t want it.

spanishExample: Dame el nombre de la persona quien estaba contigo.
englishTranslation: Give me the name of the person who was with you.

spanishExample: Esa persona, la cual estaba contigo, no quiso ir.
englishTranslation: That person, which was with you, didn’t mean to go.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)

spanishExample: Estábamos *watching TV* mientras tú *were eating.*
englishTranslation: We were watching TV while you were eating.

spanishExample: Fue ahí e iba a ir a casa también.
englishTranslation: He went there and was going to go home too.
vocabIncluded: ahí: adverb meaning "there", especially when close to the speaker or listener
e: "and" (synonym for "y", used before a word starting with an "i" sound)
iba: "was going", "he/she/it was going" (Ir, imperfect, 3rd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Fue un buen día, aunque no me dio lo que quería.
englishTranslation: It was a good day, even though he didn’t give me what I wanted.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: La persona con quien yo estaba va a darte la cosa.
englishTranslation: The person who I was with is going to give you the thing.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Madre e hija le dan algo a la familia.
englishTranslation: Mother and daughter give something to the family.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
e: "and" (synonym for "y", used before a word starting with an "i" sound)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Me dieron *a cup de tea,* pues estábamos en su casa.
englishTranslation: They gave me a cup of tea for we were at their house.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: Me diste trabajo u oportunidad, pero no los dos.
englishTranslation: You gave me work or opportunity, but not both.
vocabIncluded: me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)

spanishExample: Muchos dicen que no es bueno *to exercise* mientras *you eat.*
englishTranslation: Many say that it is not good to exercise while you eat.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: No quiero que te dé sus cosas de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I don’t want him to give you his things back.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Quiere que yo le dé esa cosa, la cual no era grande.
englishTranslation: He wants me to give him that thing, which was not big.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Quiero que Andrés u Omar te den eso.
englishTranslation: I want Andrés or Omar to give you that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
u: "or" (synonym for "o", used before a word starting with an "o" sound)

spanishExample: Quiero que les des lo que siempre les das.
englishTranslation: I want you to give them what you always give them.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: Se lo da a su hermana, pues se tiene que ir.
englishTranslation: He is giving it to his sister, for he has to leave.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Sé que tienes mucho tiempo, pero yo no tengo mucho.
englishTranslation: I know you have a lot of time, but I don’t have much.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Tenemos dos hijos, los cuales son buenos.
englishTranslation: We have two kids, which are good.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)

spanishExample: Tenemos muchas cosas, las cuales no son buenas.
englishTranslation: We have many things, which aren’t good.
vocabIncluded: el cual / la cual: "which" (idiom / relative pronoun)

spanishExample: Tenemos una oportunidad, pero él quiere que le demos muchas.
englishTranslation: We have one opportunity, but he wants us to give him many.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
